length of skull, 28.1, and width of braincase, 10.7. Mandibular

Ischnoglossa nivalis Saussure, 1860:491. Type locality "near snow

line of Mt. Orizaba, Veracruz."


Leptonycteris nivalis: Miller, 1900:126.
Leptonycteris nivalis longala Stains, 1957:355. Type from "12

mi. S and 2 mi. E Arteaga, 7500 ft., Coahuila."

CONTEXT AND CONTENT. Context noted in generic

summary. Subspecies are not currently recognized.

DIAGNOSIS. Leptonycteris species resemble those of the

genus Lichonycteris in that both lack third molars, but Leptonycteris
normally has lower incisors while Lichonycteris has none (Hall,

1981). A specimen of Leptonycteris nivalis that has lost its lower

incisors can be distinguished from Lichonycteris by the spacing of
the upper incisors between the canines: upper incisors of Lichonycteris are evenly and widely spaced while those of Leptonycteris
form an almost continuous line with the only notable space (if present)
being at the midline (Hall, 1981). Choeronycteris mexicana can be
distinguished by its protruding, short tail (Barbour and Davis, 1969).

Compared to L. yerbabuenae, L. nivalis has longer (7 to 8

category: Clasificación y descripción de la especie
racional: Se describen las características físicas de la especie, como el tamaño de los dientes, la longitud del cráneo y la forma de los incisores. También se menciona la diferencia entre esta especie y otras especies similares.

page_content:
Compared to L. yerbabuenae, L. nivalis has longer (7 to 8

mm on dorsum) fluffier pelage (Davis and Carter, 1962), is larger
in several cranial and external measurements (Davis and Carter,

1962), has a shorter presphenoid ridge and has deeper, and more

pronounced basisphenoidal pits (Watkins et al., 1972). L. nivalis
has a longer (>105 mm) third finger, with the sum of the lengths FIG. 1. Side view of facial region of Leptonycteris nivalis
of the three phalanges of the third finger averaging greater than the showing long protrusile tongue and bat fly ventral to eye. Specimen,
length of the third metacarpal (Barbour and Davis, 1969; Hoff- from Big Bend National Park, Texas, photographed in 1967 by D.
meister, 1957). L. nivalis has a longer (10% or more) head and A. Easterla.

Leon: Cerro Potosi near La Joha, 3,503 m (Koestner, 1941). L.
nivalis is rare throughout its range (Barbour and Davis, 1969).

FOSSIL RECORD. Late Pleistocene material of L. nivalis

has been reported from a travertine ledge in a cave, Cueva de Ab
in tropical southern Tamaulipas, Mexico (Dalquest and Roth, 19
Fig. 3). The material from this site is a lower jaw without teeth

FORM AND FUNCTION. Leptonycteris nivalis possess

as many as 22 deciduous teeth: i 2/1, c 1/1, p 2-3/2-3 (Philli

1971). Variability in the deciduous premolar count probably resu

from the small size of the teeth, their early loss, or their reabsorpt
before birth. The first upper premolars are not replaced by permane

page_content:
**A** **CKNOWLEDGMENTS**

I would first like to thank the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, Bat Conservation

International, and Texas Parks and Wildlife for the funding of the Mexican long-nosed bat

monitoring project which enabled me to collect my samples from Emory Cave. Additional

funding for my thesis research came from the Angelo State Graduate Research Fellowship

Program and the Head of the River Ranch research grant. I would also like to thank the U.S.

Fish and Wildlife Service, Texas Parks and Wildlife Department, and National Park Service

(especially Raymond Skiles) for permitting my research activities.

I am also grateful for the collaboration with Dr. Rodrigo Medellín, Dr. Ana Ibarra,

and Roberto Trejo from Universidad Autónoma de Mexico. By exchanging DNA samples

from Emory Cave and Cueva del Diablo, Roberto and I were able to expand our projects to

be more profound and meaningful. I also obtained additional tissues for the preliminary lab

trials from the Angelo State Natural History Collection (ASNHC) and Texas Tech University

– Natural Science Research Laboratory (TTU-NSRL). I would like to thank Dianna Krejsa

for her help with the ASNHC specimens, and both Heath Garner and Clint Perkins for their

assistance in getting the tissue loans from the TTU-NSRL.

Aside from the professional acknowledgements, there are many people I want to

thank for helping me to accomplish earning my Master’s degree. First off, I need to thank Dr.

Loren Ammerman, my advising chair. For one, she selected me as her research assistant in

the monitoring project, but she has done so much more for me. I cannot express enough the

gratitude I have for the amazing memories out in the field, the constant advice and

encouragement she has given me over the past couple of years, and the pushing she has done

iii

to help me do my best. I also would like to thank Dr. Robert Dowler and Dr. Nicholas

Negovetich for the advice they gave me as part of my committee, as well as the other input

they have had in my graduate career in courses or otherwise. I have to also give tremendous

thanks to Jody Casares, the Biology Department’s office coordinator. She helped me every

time I needed to order materials, figure out my account balances, or simply needed a friendly

face to chat with or a piece of chocolate.

Fellow students, friends, and alumni were also a big part of my success in this project.

A big thank you to Krysta Demere, Mary Gilmore, Christian Herrera, Hannah Jones, and

Rebecca Scott for all melting your faces off with me and Dr. Ammerman, when we

experienced the hottest days in the Chisos Mountains in over a decade in order to acquire the

tissue samples I used in this study. I would also like to thank Sydney Decker, Sam Harrison,

and Brent Wesley for their assistance in the lab. Whether it was helping me with some lab

procedures or just shooting ideas back and forth, they were incredibly helpful to me

throughout this project.

There are also of course the close friends that I made while in graduate school. You

guys had my back whenever I was at a low or did not feel I was good enough to get through

my degree and were the people I could just enjoy life with while in San Angelo. You know

who you are and there is no way I could have done this without you. Finally, a great thanks

to my family. They helped me financially and emotionally whenever necessary. I cannot ever

express to you fully how much I appreciate the never-ending support I received from you all

throughout these past couple of years. It is thanks to you that I have accomplished everything

that I have. I love you all and hope that you are as proud of this project as I am.

page_content:
**A** **BSTRACT**

Mexican long-nosed bats ( _Leptonycteris nivalis_ ) are endangered, migratory

nectarivores. It is important to assess genetic variability in endangered species, because

genetic variability is generally associated with adaptive potential. I tested 43 microsatellite

markers designed for related species to test their effectiveness in _L. nivalis_ . Twelve loci

developed for _L. yerbabuenae_ and four for _Glossophaga soricina_ amplified _L. nivalis_ DNA,

and of those 16 loci, seven loci from _L. yerbabuenae_ were useful in genetic analyses. Genetic

variation in _L. nivalis_ was higher than expected for an endangered bat, yet comparable to

other migratory bats. Also, there was no genetic differentiation in this species between the

two of the most geographically segregated roost sites currently known. The level of variation

detected in this species is encouraging for its future, but the suggested panmixia of this

species implies the need for conserving migratory routes in addition to foraging and roosting

habitat.


-----
author: Roxanne

**A** **BSTRACT**

Mexican long-nosed bats ( _Leptonycteris nivalis_ ) are endangered, migratory

nectarivores. It is important to assess genetic variability in endangered species, because

genetic variability is generally associated with adaptive potential. I tested 43 microsatellite

markers designed for related species to test their effectiveness in _L. nivalis_ . Twelve loci

developed for _L. yerbabuenae_ and four for _Glossophaga soricina_ amplified _L. nivalis_ DNA,

and of those 16 loci, seven loci from _L. yerbabuenae_ were useful in genetic analyses. Genetic

variation in _L. nivalis_ was higher than expected for an endangered bat, yet comparable to

other migratory bats. Also, there was no genetic differentiation in this species between the

two of the most geographically segregated roost sites currently known. The level of variation

detected in this species is encouraging for its future, but the suggested panmixia of this

species implies the need for conserving migratory routes in addition to foraging and roosting

habitat.


-----
racional: El texto menciona que se probaron 43 marcadores microsatélites diseñados para especies relacionadas para probar su efectividad en _L. nivalis_. Doce loci desarrollados para _L. yerbabuenae_ y cuatro para _Glossophaga soricina_ amplificaron el ADN de _L. nivalis_. De esos 16 loci, siete loci de _L. yerbabuenae_ fueron útiles en los análisis genéticos. La variación genética en _L. nivalis_ fue mayor de lo esperado para un murciélago en peligro de extinción, pero comparable a otros murciélagos migratorios. Además, no hubo diferenciación genética en esta especie entre los dos sitios de refugio más segregados geográficamente conocidos actualmente.

page_content:
**I** **NTRODUCTION**

The chiropteran family Phyllostomidae consists of New World leaf-nosed bats, within

which is the subfamily Glossophaginae, a group of nectarivorous bats with long snouts and

extensible tongues. The largest-bodied of this subfamily is the Mexican long-nosed bat

( _Leptonycteris nivalis_ ), an important and endangered pollinator that ranges from southern

Mexico to southern New Mexico and western Texas (Simmons 2005; Fig. 1). Throughout

much of its range, _L. nivalis_ is sympatric with its sister species, the lesser long-nosed bat ( _L._

_yerbabuenae_ ; Bogan et al. 2017). The two species specialize in habitats where they share

geographic distribution, as _L. nivalis_ tends to inhabit montane pine-oak forests at elevations

of 1000 to 2300 m, while _L. yerbabuenae_ occurs in the lower elevations of the desert floor

(Baker and Cockrum 1966; Arita 1991). The altitudinal distinction between the habitats of

these sister species might be explained by the physiological adaptations of _L. nivalis_ . This

species can feed on a wider range of nectar resources, varying in sugar concentration 5–35%

wt./vol., because of its ability to tolerate changes in volumetric intake, otherwise known as

compensatory feeding (Ayala-Berdon et al. 2013). This physical capability is lacking in _L._

_yerbabuenae_, which only can feed on more concentrated nectar sources. This physiological

constraint in _L. yerbabuenae_ is thought to prevent it from being able to tolerate colder

environments (Ayala-Berdon et al. 2013). Because _L. nivalis_ is able to inhabit higher

elevations and colder temperatures than its sister species (Arita 1991), competition for

resources where these two are sympatric is likely reduced.

The Mexican long-nosed bat is thought to migrate along a geographic corridor

__________
Journal of Mammalogy

page_content:
**Fig. 1.** —Distribution of _Leptonycteris nivalis_ . The two study sites where samples were

collected for this project are shown by the black square (Emory Cave) and the black circle

(Cueva del Diablo). Emory Cave is the only known maternity roost of this species within the

United States. Cueva del Diablo is the only known mating roost for this species across its

entire range.


-----
author: Roxanne
creator: Acrobat PDFMaker 15 for Word

collected for this project are shown by the black square (Emory Cave) and the black circle

page_content:
characterized by flowering agaves (Moreno-Valdez et al. 2004; Gomez-Ruiz and Lacher

2017), but information on basic biological characteristics is lacking (U.S. Fish and Wildlife

Service 1994), such as exact migratory routes, stopover roosts, and foraging grounds. This

bat is considered rare throughout its range (Easterla 1972; Ammerman et al. 2012) and has

been suggested to have experienced a population decline (Wilson 1985; Shull 1988). As a

result, _L. nivalis_ was given the status of endangered by the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service

(USFWS) and has since also been recognized by the International Union for the

Conservation of Nature (IUCN), Mexico, and the states of Texas and New Mexico as being a

conservation concern. A review of rapid population declines in vertebrate species suggested

that many threatened vertebrates began experiencing declines on average in the late 19 [th]

century and are at 5% of their historical population size (Li et al. 2016); such major

reductions in population size are generally accompanied by a loss of genetic diversity. The

adaptive potential for a species is dependent on having sufficient levels of genetic diversity,

so when a species is reduced to a shallow gene pool, it is less capable of evolving adaptations

to a changing environment (Willoughby et al. 2015; Li et al. 2016).

The effective population size ( _N_ _e_ ) of a species is the number of individuals in an

idealized population that exhibits the same genetic properties as the focal population (Avise

2004). Effective population size is usually much smaller than census population size ( _N_ ),

with a conservative estimate of _N_ _e_ / _N_ ratio of 0.14 across a variety of taxonomic groups

(herpetofauna, mammals, birds, fish, insects, plants, and more; Palstra and Ruzzante 2008).

The dramatically lower _N_ _e_ compared to _N_ in most wild populations typically is due to one or
author: Roxanne
creator: Acrobat PDFMaker 15 for Word
text:
characterized by flowering agaves (Moreno-Valdez et al. 2004; Gomez-Ruiz and Lacher

2017), but information on basic biological characteristics is lacking (U.S. Fish and Wildlife

Service 1994), such as exact migratory routes, stopover roosts, and foraging grounds. This

bat is considered rare throughout its range (Easterla 1972; Ammerman et al. 2012) and has

been suggested to have experienced a population decline (Wilson 1985; Shull 1988). As a

result, _L. nivalis_ was given the status of endangered by the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service

(USFWS) and has since also been recognized by the International Union for the

Conservation of Nature (IUCN), Mexico, and the states of Texas and New Mexico as being a

conservation concern. A review of rapid population declines in vertebrate species suggested

that many threatened vertebrates began experiencing declines on average in the late 19 [th]

century and are at 5% of their historical population size (Li et al. 2016); such major

reductions in population size are generally accompanied by a loss of genetic diversity. The

adaptive potential for a species is dependent on having sufficient levels of genetic diversity,

so when a species is reduced to a shallow gene pool, it is less capable of evolving adaptations

to a changing environment (Willoughby et al. 2015; Li et al. 2016).

The effective population size ( _N_ _e_ ) of a species is the number of individuals in an

idealized population that exhibits the same genetic properties as the focal population (Avise

2004). Effective population size is usually much smaller than census population size ( _N_ ),

with a conservative estimate of _N_ _e_ / _N_ ratio of 0.14 across a variety of taxonomic groups

(herpetofauna, mammals, birds, fish, insects, plants, and more; Palstra and Ruzzante 2008).

The dramatically lower _N_ _e_ compared to _N_ in most wild populations typically is due to one or

(herpetofauna, mammals, birds, fish, insects, plants, and more; Palstra and Ruzzante 2008).

The dramatically lower _N_ _e_ compared to _N_ in most wild populations typically is due to one or

more of several reasons, including skewed sex ratios, fluctuating population size, and

The dramatically lower _N_ _e_ compared to _N_ in most wild populations typically is due to one or

more of several reasons, including skewed sex ratios, fluctuating population size, and


-----
racional: Se menciona el autor y el año de publicación de un libro o artículo científico. También se menciona el título de la publicación. El contenido principalmente es bibliografía, si hay más información, usar otra categoría.

page_content:
variation in numbers of progeny (Avise 2004). In their review, Willoughby et al. (2015)

found that species with a low contemporary _N_ _e_, which frequently are listed by the IUCN as

having threatened or endangered status, tend towards lower levels of genetic diversity; this is

supported by the conservation genetics theory that suggests that a reduced _N_ _e_ results in a

more rapid loss in genetic diversity (Allendorf and Luikart 2007). As decreased diversity can

impact the long-term sustainability of a species (Willoughby et al. 2015), it is important to

assess the levels of genetic variability in species of concern. The Mexican long-nosed bat

was listed as endangered, along with the lesser long-nosed bat, on 31 October 1988 by the

USFWS. In the species recovery plan, four major tasks were identified as necessary actions

to recover the Mexican long-nosed bat, one of which was to model population viability

(USFWS 1994). In this study, I focused on a subcomponent of this task, which is to

determine the levels of genetic variability within and among populations in different

geographic areas.

While it has been suggested that _L. nivalis_ is comprised of six distinct populations

based on geographic groupings determined by Arita and Humphrey (1988), the distinction of

populations should be carefully considered as the migratory habits of the species could

hinder the accurate interpretation of grouping across its distribution (USFWS 1994). The

thesis work of Brown (2008) instead suggested that _L. nivalis_ is made up of a single

panmictic population (also see Ammerman et al. in press). Using amplified fragment length

polymorphism (AFLP; data collected for 74 individuals) DNA fingerprinting, he revealed a

lack of population subdivision throughout their range, as well as a lack of genetic structure.

Also, the geographic distribution of mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA; data collected for 72

based on geographic groupings determined by Arita and Humphrey (1988), the distinction of

Also, the geographic distribution of mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA; data collected for 72


-----
racional: El texto menciona que se usó el método AFLP para obtener la información genética. También menciona que se usó mtDNA. Se menciona el número de individuos que se usaron para la recolección de datos genéticos. Se menciona que se usó el banco genético GenBank: AY395808.1

page_content:
individuals) haplotypes rejected the hypothesis that females of this species exhibit natal

philopatry (Ammerman et al. in press). Additionally, _L. nivalis_ seemed to show relatively

low to moderate levels of genetic diversity for a migratory bat, but not at such low levels as

might be expected for a species that has supposedly undergone a recent and severe decline, or

genetic bottleneck (Ammerman et al. in press). High mtDNA haplotype diversity, high

proportion of singleton haplotypes, and a lack of genetic structure across a geographic

landscape, in addition to moderate diversity levels and an absence of genetic subdivision

(Brown 2008), suggest the possibility that Mexican long-nosed bats have experienced a

historical population expansion (Allendorf and Luikart 2007). However, results from

neutrality tests (Tajima’s _D_ and _R2_ ) and the mismatch distribution from Ammerman et al. (in

press) do not necessarily concur with historical growth in this species, and therefore there is

no clear conclusion on this matter. While the levels of genetic diversity found in _L. nivalis_

seem to contradict the idea that this species has undergone a major bottleneck event, this

could be skewed by a number of factors, such as high migration rates, mutation rates, and

pre-bottleneck diversity (Busch et al. 2007; Peery et al. 2012). Furthermore, the method of

using AFLP fingerprinting could result in a greater estimate of DNA polymorphism than is

true if there is incomplete restriction of the DNA, thus causing an over-estimate of genetic

diversity (Vos et al. 1995). This thesis work was profound in contradicting the well-accepted

idea that there are separate populations within the distribution of _L. nivalis_, but Brown (2008)

was unable to make estimates of _N_ _e_ . An important next step in assessing the status of this

endangered species is to explore this concept.

page_content:
Microsatellite markers are codominant, non-coding, presumably neutral sequences of

DNA that are commonly used to provide estimates of genetic diversity of a population

(Willoughby et al. 2015). These highly polymorphic molecular markers contain varying

tandem repeat units that are about two to five nucleotides long, with notable heterozygosity

levels and allelic richness (Avise 2004). They have been applied in molecular studies for

different groups and their use in bats has been exemplified by several studies (e.g., Salguiero

et al. 2010; Korstian et al. 2015; Lee et al. 2015; Arteaga et al. 2018). For example, Lee et al.

(2015) used microsatellites to assess heterozygosity and population connectivity in the

endangered Ozark big-eared bat ( _Corynorhinus townsendii ingens_ ). Korstian et al. (2015)

also studied microsatellite loci in two migratory tree bats of the genus _Lasiurus_, assessing

contemporary and long-term _N_ _e_, as well as determining that both species were represented by

a single, continuous population. These molecular markers have grown to be popular genetic

tools and have been applied in a variety of disciplines, including population genetics and

conservation biology (Abdul-Muneer 2014).

There have been few studies that examined genetics of the genus _Leptonycteris_ (but

see Arteaga et al. 2018), let alone the genetics of _L. nivalis_ . In her thesis work, Ramos-Frias

(2013) measured the genetic diversity of _L. nivalis_ in central Mexico using four microsatellite

loci previously isolated and characterized for _L. yerbabuenae_ by Ramirez et al. (2011) to

genotype 37 samples at one location and 29 samples at the other. The _L. nivalis_ populations

both showed high polymorphism and diversity, but calculated heterozygosity was lower than

expected. Additionally, she found high gene flow between the populations. Both observations

concur with Brown’s thesis work (2008), but her populations were within 40 km of each

racional: El texto describe el uso de marcadores microsatélites para estimar la diversidad genética de una población. También menciona estudios previos que han utilizado marcadores microsatélites para estudiar la genética de los murciélagos. Además, el texto menciona la diversidad genética de _L. nivalis_ y los estudios previos que han examinado la genética del género _Leptonycteris_. Por lo tanto, el texto pertenece a la categoría "Genética de la especie".

page_content:
other. The Mexican long-nosed bat is known to travel over 20 km one-way to forage in a

night, or to commute to alternate roost sites (Bogan et al. 2017). While it would be a costly

undertaking to travel almost 40 km, it is possible that resource availability could be enough

incentive for some groups of bats to travel such a distance in a single night (Bogan et al.

2017). A more thorough analysis of the population genetics using an increased number of

microsatellite markers across more geographically separated populations of this species

should be able to provide insight into the level of continuity this species exhibits across its

range, as well as provide an estimation of _N_ _e_ for these bats.

There have been a couple of studies that have developed primer sets for microsatellite

loci for _L. yerbabuenae_, both of which suggested the usability of a portion of their sets for _L._

_nivalis_ in cross-species amplification (Ramirez et al. 2011; Romero-Meza et al. 2012).

Additionally, microsatellite loci have been isolated and characterized for another closely

related species, Pallas’ long-tongued bat ( _Glossophaga soricina_ ; Wetterer et al. 2000),

although cross-species amplification has not been confirmed for this set (Oprea et al. 2012).

With the availability of these tools developed for closely related taxa, I hypothesized that

these microsatellite markers could be used in the Mexican long-nosed bat to assess the

genetic variability of this internationally endangered bat.

There were two main objectives of this study: (1) undergo cross-species amplification

trials with the three microsatellite loci sets designed by Ramirez et al. (2011), Romero-Meza

et al. (2012), and Oprea et al. (2012) to establish a set of microsatellite loci that can

effectively be used in genetic studies of _Leptonycteris nivalis_, and (2) assess the genetic

variability and connectivity of two of the most geographically separated _Leptonycteris nivalis_

page_content:
**M** **ATERIALS AND** **M** **ETHODS**

_Study Site_

Bats for this study were sampled from two sites. The first site, Emory Cave, is

located in the Chisos Mountains in Big Bend National Park, Brewster County, Texas (Fig. 1).

_Leptonycteris nivalis_ was discovered at Emory Cave on 26 July 1937 (Borell and Bryant

1942); it is the only known roost site for this species within Texas and only is occupied from

April to September (Ammerman et al. 2009; Adams 2015). Emory Cave is at an elevation of

2255 m (Easterla 1972), consisting of three rooms with extensions of various crevices and

passageways that require professional climbing gear to access, and a single main entryway

that accounts for all bat traffic in and out of the cave (Veni 2016). A small skylight exists

high on a west-facing bluff above the entryway, but this opening is partially obstructed by

vegetation and has been determined to have no traffic going in or out during emergence

periods (Ammerman et al. 2009).

The second study site where bats were sampled is the only known mating roost of this

species, Cueva del Diablo, located in Tepoztlan, Morelos, Mexico (Fig. 1). The habitat

features surrounding this cave are similar to Emory Cave, as Cueva del Diablo is at an

elevation of 1883 m and vegetation includes temperate forest composed of _Pinus_ and

_Quercus_ species (Sanchez and Medellín 2007). Despite Brown’s (2008) findings that _L._

_nivalis_ is made up of a panmictic population, it is still unclear as to whether or not the same

individuals use both caves.

_Sample Collection and DNA Extraction_

Bats were captured at Emory Cave via harp trapping near the cave entrance on 17, 19,

_Sample Collection and DNA Extraction_

Bats were captured at Emory Cave via harp trapping near the cave entrance on 17, 19,

category: Tipo de ambiente en donde se desarrolla la especie
racional: Se describe el tipo de vegetación, la altitud y la temperatura de los dos sitios donde se capturaron los murciélagos.

page_content:
and 21 June 2017. Species, age, sex, and reproductive state were assessed, as well as

measurements of weight (g), and forearm length (mm). For any bats that were not identified

as _L. nivalis_, their species, age, and sex were recorded and then they were released without

taking morphometric measurements. As part of another study, _L. nivalis_ were injected with

passive integrative transponder (PIT) tags, following the methods of Adams (2015). A single

biopsy punch was taken from the plagiopatagium of each tagged Mexican long-nosed bat

using a sterile 3 mm biopsy punch (Miltex, Inc., York, Pennsylvania) pressed against a clean

cutting board surface, as long as the bat did not seem stressed (Appendix I). Laboratory

identification numbers were assigned to each wing punch, based on the last three digits of

that individual’s PIT tag number. Each of the wing-punches were stored in 500 µl of lysis

buffer (Longmire et al. 1997) that was already aliquoted into screwtop microtubes, and the

bats were released after being fed ~10% sucrose solution. A similar procedure for wing
punching was followed by a collaborator from Universidad Nacional Autónoma de México

(UNAM), Roberto Trejo, who provided DNA samples from Cueva del Diablo (Appendix I).

These tissue samples were stored in 70% ethanol, which has been shown to be a good

preservative for DNA and other macromolecules (Corthals et al. 2015), until DNA extraction

that was performed one day later (Roberto E. Trejo-Salazar, UNAM, Mexico City, Mexico,

personal communication, April, 2018). All handling procedures and equipment

decontamination abided by White-nose Syndrome protocol (USFWS 2016), followed ASM

guidelines (Sikes et al. 2016), and were approved by the IACUC committees of Angelo State

University (#16-10; Appendix II) and the National Park Service

(IMR_BIBE_Ammerman_MexicanLongnosedBat_2016.A2). These research activities were

10

page_content:
permitted by the USFWS (#TE127287-1), National Park Service (BIBE-2017-SCI-004), and

Texas Parks and Wildlife Department (#SPR-0994-703).

I extracted whole genomic DNA from the wing punch samples from Emory Cave

using a DNeasy Blood & Tissue Kit (QIAGEN, Inc., Valencia, California), following the

manufacturer’s protocol with the exception of eluting the DNA from the spin column in three

separate elutions of 50 µl of AE buffer each. The phenol-chloroform-isoamyl alcohol DNA

extraction protocol (Sambrook et al. 1989) was used for extracting the DNA from the wing

punch samples collected at Cueva del Diablo (Roberto E. Trejo-Salazar, UNAM, Mexico

City, Mexico, personal communication, April, 2018). The concentrations (ng/µl) of these

DNA extractions were assessed using a Qubit 3.0 Fluorometer with a dsDNA HS Assay Kit

(ThermoFisher Scientific, Waltham, Massachusetts), following the manufacturer’s protocol.

I used the same DNA extraction protocol on liver samples from specimens of both the

Angelo State Natural History Collection (ASNHC) and the Texas Tech University – Natural

Science Research Laboratory (TTU-NSRL). Specimens of _L. nivalis_ (from the ASNHC:

ASK11604, ASK11605, ASK11606) were used for optimizing PCR conditions for the

microsatellites being tested. This way, the limited DNA from the wing punches collected in

the field could be reserved for the final data collection. Specimens of _G. soricina_ (from the

ASNHC: ASK406) and _L. yerbabuenae_ (from the TTU-NSRL: TK148374, TK148407,

TK40313, TK40306) were used as positive controls for their respective microsatellite

markers when attempting cross-species amplification with _L. nivalis_ DNA.

_Microsatellite Loci and PCR_

There were nine microsatellite loci that were identified by Ramirez et al. (2011) as

separate elutions of 50 µl of AE buffer each. The phenol-chloroform-isoamyl alcohol DNA

extraction protocol (Sambrook et al. 1989) was used for extracting the DNA from the wing

punch samples collected at Cueva del Diablo (Roberto E. Trejo-Salazar, UNAM, Mexico

City, Mexico, personal communication, April, 2018). The concentrations (ng/µl) of these

DNA extractions were assessed using a Qubit 3.0 Fluorometer with a dsDNA HS Assay Kit

(ThermoFisher Scientific, Waltham, Massachusetts), following the manufacturer’s protocol.

I used the same DNA extraction protocol on liver samples from specimens of both the

Angelo State Natural History Collection (ASNHC) and the Texas Tech University – Natural

Science Research Laboratory (TTU-NSRL). Specimens of _L. nivalis_ (from the ASNHC:

ASK11604, ASK11605, ASK11606) were used for optimizing PCR conditions for the

microsatellites being tested. This way, the limited DNA from the wing punches collected in

the field could be reserved for the final data collection. Specimens of _G. soricina_ (from the

ASNHC: ASK406) and _L. yerbabuenae_ (from the TTU-NSRL: TK148374, TK148407,

TK40313, TK40306) were used as positive controls for their respective microsatellite

markers when attempting cross-species amplification with _L. nivalis_ DNA.

_Microsatellite Loci and PCR_

There were nine microsatellite loci that were identified by Ramirez et al. (2011) as

11


-----
racional: El texto describe el proceso de extracción de ADN de muestras de murciélagos, utilizando diferentes métodos y kits. También menciona el uso de muestras de hígado para la extracción de ADN y la optimización de las condiciones de PCR para los microsatélites que se están probando. Además, menciona el uso de muestras de otras especies como controles positivos para la amplificación entre especies con ADN de L. nivalis.

page_content:
successful in cross-species amplification for _L. nivalis_ in Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR;

Table 1; Appendix III). Four of these loci (Leye11, Leye17, Leye23, and LeyeL71) were

confirmed for use in _L. nivalis_ in the thesis by Ramos-Frias (2013). I contacted authors from

the Romero-Meza et al. (2012) study, as there was no indication given in the publication

about which were successful in cross-species amplification, but only was informed that 19 of

24 isolated loci for _L. yerbabuenae_ were usable for _L. nivalis_ and not provided details on

which primer sets amplified _L. nivalis_ DNA successfully. Therefore, I tested all 24 loci from

Romero-Meza et al. (2012) for usability in this study (Table 1; Appendix III). All

microsatellite loci isolated by Oprea et al. (2012) for _G. soricina_ also were tested, as no

published research had yet attempted their use in _Leptonycteris_ .

I conducted PCR using the QIAGEN Microsatellite Type-It Kit (QIAGEN, Inc.,

Valencia, California), which provided a PCR master mix containing DNA polymerase,

MgCl 2, and a mix of dNTPs. Reactions were first performed in 12.5 µl volumes, which

included 6.25 µl of master mix, 2.25 µl of primers for a particular locus (equal amounts of

forward primer solution and reverse primer solution, each 5µM), 2–12 ng of DNA, and the

remaining volume filled with sterile RNase free water. As reagents started to become limited,

that recipe was halved for the remaining reactions. I optimized PCR conditions for each of

the microsatellite loci by using gel electrophoresis to assess the PCR products. This was done

with a 1.5% agarose gel, made with 1X Sodium Borate (NaB) buffer, containing 0.01%

ethidium bromide to stain the DNA, and PCR products were visualized under ultraviolet light

after electrophoresis. This method was useful in determining what needed to be changed

about the PCR cycling conditions, whether it was annealing temperature, amount of DNA

12

page_content:
used, or otherwise. Once I optimized PCR conditions for the successful microsatellite

markers using the DNA extracted from liver samples, I conducted PCR for the DNA samples

from Emory Cave and Cueva del Diablo (Appendix I) with all usable loci. I conducted

reactions with optimized loci using WellRed dye-labeled forward primers (Table 1), so that

the products could be used for fragment analysis in a capillary electrophoretic genetic

analysis system, scored against a 400 DNA size standard (CEQ8000, Beckman-Coulter,

Brea, California). I scored individual genotypes at each locus by eye. Throughout the lab

procedures, I reanalyzed a subset of the samples to identify and quantify scoring errors

(DeWoody et al. 2006).

_Analysis_

Before analyzing the scored genotypes, I first determined frequencies of null alleles,

which are alleles at loci that consistently fail to amplify to detectable levels via PCR (Dakin

and Avise 2004). All loci were analyzed for null alleles using the program FreeNA (50,000

iterations; Chapuis and Estoup 2007). I also assessed scoring errors due to stutter and large
allele dropout using MicroChecker v 2.2.3 (Van Oosterhout et al. 2004). Some loci produce

stutter band patterns due to slipping by _Taq_ polymerase, causing the interpretation of whether

an individual is a homozygote or a heterozygote to be difficult (Van Oosterhout et al. 2004).

Large allele dropout results from the preferential amplification of the smaller allele in a

heterozygous genotype, which combined with stutter patterns creates a concern for a

substantial bias in data interpretation (DeWoody et al. 2006). I also tested microsatellite loci

for deviation from Hardy-Weinberg Equilibrium (HWE) and genotypic disequilibrium

between pairs of loci using the Markov chain approximation (dememorization: 10,000;

15

-----
racional: Se menciona el tipo de tejido que se usó para obtener la secuenciación. El tipo de marcador: 12S tRNA-Val (AY395808 GenBank) (Baker et al., 2003). El ID del banco genético GenBank: AY395808.1

page_content:
batches: 1,000; iterations per batch: 10,000) in GENEPOP v 4.7.0 (Raymond and Rousset

1995; Rousset 2008). A Bonferroni correction was used to adjust _P_ -values for multiple

pairwise comparisons in R (R Core Team 2018).

I assessed genetic variation using GenAlEx v 6.5 (Peakall and Smouse 2006, 2012) to

calculate levels of both observed and expected heterozygosity ( _H_ _O_ and _H_ _E_, respectively), as

well as mean number of alleles per locus ( _N_ _A_ ) and number of private alleles per population

( _N_ _P_ ). Differences in genetic diversity were assessed using two-sample t-tests in R (R Core

Team 2018). Allelic richness ( _AR_ ), defined as a measure of the number of alleles per locus,

independent of sample size, was estimated using FSTAT v 2.9.4 (Goudet 1995, 2003).

GenAlEx also calculated _F_ _ST_, a coefficient by Wright (1965) that is frequently used as a

measure of population structure (Meirmans and Hedrick 2011). The product of effective

population size ( _N_ ) and rate of migration between sites ( _m_ ) could then be calculated from the

_F_ _ST_ value as a measure of gene flow. This was accomplished using Wright’s (1984)

estimator: _Nm_ = (1 / _F_ _ST_ – 1) / 4. Additionally, after producing pairwise genetic distances for

binary data following the method of Huff et al. (1993), GenAlEx was used for a principal

coordinates analysis (PCoA) for further examination of genetic differentiation between the

roost sites (Peakall and Smouse 2006, 2012).

An assessment of population sub-structure was conducted using the Bayesian

clustering method implemented in STRUCTURE v 2.3.4 (Pritchard et al. 2000). This method

identifies the number of genetic clusters within a sample, deciphered as the number of

genetically distinct populations. Ten independent runs were performed at each assumed

population number ( _K_ = 1 – 5), using an admixture model with correlated allele frequencies.

16

An assessment of population sub-structure was conducted using the Bayesian

racional: Se menciona el uso de software para el análisis de genética de la especie, así como los métodos utilizados para el análisis de la variación genética, la estructura de la población y la subestructura de la población.

page_content:
The length of the burn-in period and the number of Markov Chain Monte Carlo repetitions

after the burn-in were set to 100,000 and 1,000,000, respectively. I used the Evanno et al.

(2005) method to find the optimum number of assumed population clusters by calculating Δ _K_

in STRUCTURE HARVESTER v 0.6.94 (Earl and vonHoldt 2012) for each of the tested _K_

values. From this, the modal value of Δ _K_ could be determined to find the true number of

populations. The output from STRUCTURE HARVESTER for the optimal _K_ value was then

used in CLUMPP v 1.1.2 (Jakobsson and Rosenberg 2007) to average the individual

membership coefficients from the 10 STRUCTURE iterations, using the FullSearch

algorithm. I produced a graphical display of the individual membership across all samples

from both sites using STRUCTURE PLOT v 2.0 (Ramasamey et al. 2014).

Contemporary _N_ _e_ was calculated by testing for microsatellite linkage disequilibrium

using N E Estimator v2 (Do et al. 2014). I assumed random mating and conducted two

estimates: (1) a more conservative estimate that screened out alleles with frequencies below

0.05, and (2) a less conservative estimate that screened out alleles with frequencies below

0.02.

17


-----

page_content:
**R** **ESULTS**

_Sample Collection and DNA Extraction_

The harp-trapping events at Emory Cave resulted in the capture of five species of bats

besides our target species, including big brown bat ( _Eptesicus fuscus_ ), Yuma myotis ( _Myotis_

_yumanensis_ ), fringed myotis ( _M. thysanodes_ ), Western small-footed myotis ( _M. ciliolabrum_ ),

and Townsend’s big-eared bat ( _Corynorhinus townsendii_ ). As for _L. nivalis_, a total of 106

was captured, processed, and sampled (Appendix I). The only adult bats captured were

female, while juvenile and subadult bats were a mixture of males and females (Table 2). The

majority of the adult females were lactating, indicating that they were mothers with volant

juveniles at the cave, but two were classified as non-reproductive. Weight ranged from 17 to

37 g, while forearm length ranged from 53.3 to 60.7 mm. A total of 61 Mexican long-nosed

bats was captured at Cueva del Diablo during Roberto Trejo’s harp-trapping events

(Appendix I). All individuals were adults, with a relatively even mixture of males and

females (Table 2). Most of these bats were non-reproductive, but five males were identified

as being scrotal. Weight ranged from 19.5 to 40.5 g, while forearm length ranged from 53.9

to 59.8 mm. The DNA extracted from all 106 bats sampled at Emory Cave had a range in

yield of 0.719–8.20 ng/μl. There were 51 DNA samples provided by Roberto Trejo from bats

captured at Cueva del Diablo to be used in this study, and those samples had a DNA yield

range of 0.684–4.530 ng/μl. A total of 113 individuals were used in this project, including all

51 DNA samples from Cueva del Diablo and 62 of the DNA samples from Emory Cave.

_Microsatellite Loci and PCR_

A total of 43 microsatellite loci were tested in this study (Table 1; Appendix III),

18

yield of 0.719–8.20 ng/μl. There were 51 DNA samples provided by Roberto Trejo from bats

captured at Cueva del Diablo to be used in this study, and those samples had a DNA yield

range of 0.684–4.530 ng/μl. A total of 113 individuals were used in this project, including all

51 DNA samples from Cueva del Diablo and 62 of the DNA samples from Emory Cave.

_Microsatellite Loci and PCR_

A total of 43 microsatellite loci were tested in this study (Table 1; Appendix III),

racional: La tabla muestra información demográfica de la especie _Leptonycteris nivalis_, como el número de individuos capturados, su sexo, edad y estado reproductivo. Esta información es relevante para comprender la ecología y demografía de la especie.

page_content:
which included 33 isolated for _L. yerbabuenae_ (Ramirez et al. 2011; Romero-Meza et al.

2012) and ten for _G. soricina_ (Oprea et al. 2012). Only 16 primer pairs successfully

amplified _L. nivalis_ DNA, which included 12 _L. yerbabuenae_ loci and four _G. soricina_ loci

(Table 1). Seven of the _L. yerbabuenae_ loci were used in genotyping 113 samples (Appendix

IV), which included 62 bats from Emory Cave and 51 bats from Cueva del Diablo. The seven

loci that ultimately made up the dataset included in the data analysis were Leye3a, Leye11,

Leye17, LeyeL71, Leye23, Leye27, and LepyA7. Those with the “Leye” prefix were isolated

by Ramirez et al. (2011) and LepyA7 was from Romero-Meza et al. (2012). Four of the _L._

_yerbabuenae_ loci that were excluded from the analysis exhibited monomorphism (Table 1),

in which the most common allele at a locus exceeded a frequency of 0.95 (King et al. 2007).

Interestingly, LepyA2 was not monomorphic, but exhibited the same diallelic genotype

(236/255) in all individuals analyzed. Out of the four _G. soricina_ loci that amplified _L. nivalis_

DNA, three were monomorphic (GS02, GS03, and GS15). The last one (GS04) consistently

had unclear peaks, peaks only one nucleotide apart, or three peaks, and the only possible

scoring for this locus was of the same three alleles. As a result, all four of these loci were

excluded from further analysis, leaving me with a set of seven microsatellite loci

characterized for _L. yerbabuenae_ to use in data analysis of _L. nivalis_ .

A subset of the samples was re-amplified and those products analyzed to assess PCR

and scoring error. This was conducted with all seven polymorphic loci, as well as two of the

monomorphic loci (LeyeL67 and LeyeCT2). A total of 184 re-runs were conducted, between

66 individuals and nine loci, amounting to a reassessment of over 23% of the data collected.

Seven out of those 184 runs scored differently, amounting to a 3.8% error rate for both PCR

20

racional: No hay información sobre el autor, la editorial o la fecha de publicación. El texto menciona el número de individuos y loci utilizados en un estudio, lo que sugiere que se trata de información sobre un estudio científico. Por lo tanto, se clasifica como "Metadatos".

page_content:
and scoring. Even when sample numbers are low ( _n_ = 10 individuals per population),

estimates of genetic diversity and structure are robust to genotyping error rates as long as

they do not exceed 30% (Smith and Wang 2014). As such, the genotyping error rate found in

this study was unlikely to bias the results of these analyses.

_Analysis_

Null allele frequencies were calculated for each locus at each roost site and resulted in

only LeyeL71 at Cueva del Diablo showing frequency higher than 0.2 (0.2266; Table 3).

There were three other null allele frequencies that were greater than 0.1, but less than 0.2,

and those were for LeyeL71 at Emory Cave (0.1503), LepyA7 at Cueva del Diablo (0.1408),

and Leye27 at both sites (0.1746 and 0.1908; Table 3). The rest of the calculated null allele

frequencies were negligible to zero (< 0.1). The presence of null alleles will likely cause a

downward bias in estimates of genetic diversity, which must be kept in mind when

interpreting results in genetic variation. They are also known to cause an overestimation of

_F_ _ST_ and genetic distance when there is significant differentiation between populations, but

_F_ _ST_ estimates are unaffected when there is a lack of genetic structure (Chapuis and Estoup

2007). There was no evidence of large allele dropout for any of the loci in either population.

However, there was evidence of stuttering causing scoring errors. This was indicated by a

significant shortage of heterozygote genotypes with alleles of one repeat unit difference. This

occurred in LeyeL71 and LepyA7 at Cueva del Diablo, as well as Leye27 at both roost sites.

When testing whether or not the loci were in HWE, LeyeL71, LepyA7, and Leye27

had significant _P_ -values suggesting that they were not in HWE, even after using Bonferroni

corrections to adjust the _P_ -values (Table 4). LeyeL71 and Leye27 had _P_ _adj_ < 0.05 in all three

21

racional: Se menciona el tipo de análisis genético realizado (pruebas de equilibrio de Hardy-Weinberg) y el software utilizado (GENEPOP v 4.7.0). Se incluyen los valores de p ajustados utilizando una corrección de Bonferroni.

page_content:
HWE tests (global, Emory, and Diablo), but LepyA7 only deviated significantly from HWE

( _P_ _adj_ < 0.05) in the global and Emory tests. The other four loci had insignificant _P_ _adj_ values,

suggesting they did not fall out of HWE for this dataset (Table 4). In Fisher’s test for

genotypic linkage disequilibrium, for both global and Diablo datasets, LeyeL71 and LepyA7

had significant Bonferroni adjusted _P_ -values (Global: _P_ _adj_ = 0.0111; Diablo: _P_ _adj_ = 0.0303),

suggesting that their genotypes were not independent from each other. There was no

significant linkage disequilibrium found in the Fisher’s test for individuals from Emory

Cave. When conducting a population genetic structure analysis with the admixture model in

STRUCTURE, the program assumes linkage equilibrium and HWE within populations

(Falush et al. 2003). Furthermore, strong linkage disequilibrium can cause STRUCTURE to

overestimate the number of genetic clusters present across samples (Kaeuffer et al. 2007).

With both significant deviation from HWE and linkage disequilibrium in some of these loci,

it was thus warranted to conduct parallel genetic structure analyses: one with all seven loci

included and one exclusive to the four loci that did not break either of these assumptions.

In estimating genetic diversity levels, _N_ _A_ for both roost sites ranged from 6 to 22, _H_ _O_

ranged from 0.431 to 0.919, and _H_ _E_ ranged from 0.678 to 0.933 (Table 5). There was no

difference in the diversity levels of these two roost sites, as determined by two-sample t-tests

( _N_ _A_ : _P_ = 0.7689; _H_ _O_ : _P_ = 0.6052; _H_ _E_ : _P_ = 0.8369). The overall _AR_ ranged from 6.363 to

21.688 across all loci (Table 6). There were two private alleles in the EMO group, while

there was only one private allele in the DIA group (Table 5). There was a very low measure

of genetic differentiation between the samples from the two roost sites, as the calculated _F_ _ST_

page_content:
estimated to be 58.996. Further analysis of genetic differentiation with the PCoA also

revealed no population structuring (Fig. 2). The first axis explained 10.73% of the variation,

while the second axis explained 10.02% of the variation. The results of this analysis showed

no subdivision amongst the samples.

The first genetic structure analysis I ran included data from all seven loci, which

resulted in the mode of Δ _K_ at _K_ = 2 (Fig. 3A; LnP( _K_ ) = -3775.24; SD = 62.02). It is noted in

Evanno et al. (2005) that Δ _K_ cannot find the true _K_ if _K_ = 1 and must be used along with

other criteria such as the patterns of individual assignment (Fig. 3B) or likelihood values

(mean LnP( _K_ ); Fig. 3A). When observing the graphical display of the average individual

membership coefficients for all individuals, it is apparent that each individual had

approximately equal membership to each cluster and that there was no biologically

meaningful clustering into two groups that could be formed (Fig. 3B). However, due to the

concerns of violating assumptions of the STRUCTURE analysis (that all loci exhibit HWE

and linkage equilibrium), a second STRUCTURE analysis was conducted following the same

methods as the first analysis. In this run, the four loci that did not exhibit high null allele

frequencies, scoring error due to stutter, deviation from HWE, and linkage disequilibrium

(Leye3a, Leye11, Leye17, and Leye23) were used and the others were excluded. The modal

Δ _K_ in this case resulted in _K_ = 3 (Fig. 4A; LnP( _K_ ) = -2006.33; SD = 4.67), but as stated by

Evanno et al. (2005) low marker numbers have the great potential of causing the mode of Δ _K_

to not be at the true _K_ . When viewing the results of this analysis, it is clear that there was

complete admixture among all individuals, with all individual membership coefficients even

across all three supposed genetic clusters (Fig. 4B). This is consistent with what we would

27

page_content:
**Fig. 2.** —Results from the principal coordinates analysis for the genotype data of 113

individuals of _Leptonycteris nivalis_ . These samples were genotyped with seven microsatellite

loci. The first axis explained 10.73% of the variation and the second axis explained 10.02%.

As clearly displayed, there is no genetic subdivision recovered in this analysis. EMO =

Emory Cave; DIA = Cueva del Diablo.

28

page_content:
**Fig. 3.** —Resulting plots from the analysis conducted in STRUCTURE using seven

polymorphic loci. (A) Plot of Δ _K_ for _K_ = 1–5, used to find the modal value of Δ _K_ to

determine the optimum number of genetic clusters ( _K_ = 2). The second Y-axis plots the

values for mean likelihood, showing the highest LnP( _K_ ) value to be at _K_ = 1. (B) Bar graph

representing the individual membership coefficients of 113 _Leptonycteris nivalis_ individuals

from the two different roost sites Emory Cave (EMO) and Cueva del Diablo (DIA). Each bar

represents a single bat and the pattern of membership on this graph suggests that there is no

biologically meaningful clustering of these individuals into two groups, leading to the

conclusion that this is a panmictic population.

29

**Fig. 4.** —Resulting plots from the analysis conducted in STRUCTURE using four

polymorphic loci that did not deviate from Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium, exhibit linkage

disequilibrium, or show concerning frequencies of null alleles (close to or greater than 0.2).

(A) Plot of Δ _K_ for _K_ = 1–5, used to find the modal value of Δ _K_ to determine the optimum

number of genetic clusters ( _K_ = 3). The second Y-axis plots the values for mean likelihood,

showing the highest LnP( _K_ ) value to be at _K_ = 1. (B) Bar graph representing the individual

membership coefficients of 113 _Leptonycteris nivalis_ individuals from the two different roost

sites Emory Cave (EMO) and Cueva del Diablo (DIA). Each bar represents a single bat and

the pattern of membership on this graph suggests that there is no biologically meaningful

clustering of these individuals into three groups, leading to the conclusion that this is a

panmictic population.

30

page_content:
expect for a panmictic population, as none of the individuals can actually be assigned to a

particular cluster. Additionally, both STRUCTURE analyses resulted in peak mean LnP( _K_ )

values at _K_ = 1 (1 [st] analysis: LnP( _K_ ) = -3397.87, Fig. 3A; 2 [nd] analysis: LnP( _K_ ) = -1995.62,

Fig. 4A), further supporting that this sample comprised a single genetic cluster.

Contemporary effective population size was estimated with all samples included in

one population, based on the results of the genetic differentiation and structure analyses.

When the estimate excluded alleles with frequencies lower than 0.02, _N_ _e_ = 5723 (Jackknife

95% CI: 421.4–∞). The second estimate, which excluded alleles with frequencies lower than

0.05, was a more conservative estimate of _N_ _e_ = 570.1 (Jackknife 95% CI: 164.9–∞).

31

racional: El texto menciona el tamaño efectivo de la población, que es una medida de la variación genética dentro de una población. También menciona los alelos y sus frecuencias, que son conceptos relacionados con la genética de las poblaciones.

page_content:
**D** **ISCUSSION**

_Use of Microsatellite Markers in Cross-Species Amplification_

At the beginning of this study, it seemed likely that there would be a large set of

microsatellite loci to work with when conducting a genetic analysis on _Leptonycteris nivalis_ .

Unfortunately, this did not turn out to be the case. Ramirez et al. (2011) suggested the

usability of nine of the markers isolated and characterized for _L. yerbabuenae_ in cross
species amplification, but one of those was unsuccessful despite several optimization

attempts with modified annealing temperatures, template DNA concentrations, or additives in

the PCR mix (Appendix III). Additionally, out of the eight that did amplify _L. nivalis_ DNA,

two were monomorphic and two others deviated from HWE, exhibited linkage

disequilibrium, and had concerning frequencies of null alleles. Ascertainment bias is a

common issue when attempting cross-species amplification, meaning that loci that exhibit

polymorphism in their source species are often less variable and even monomorphic in

closely related species (Delport et al. 2006). Still, the set by Ramirez et al. (2011) provided

six polymorphic loci to work with in this study. The second study that isolated microsatellites

in _L. yerbabuenae_ (Romero-Meza et al. 2011) published that 19 of 24 loci would be

functional in cross-species amplification. However, with no specifics on which loci worked

in _L. nivalis_ provided in the article or by the authors, all 24 required testing. I found that

substantially fewer of these loci amplified _L. nivalis_ DNA than suggested by the article (four

instead of 19 out of 24), with three out of those four loci proving to be monomorphic and

uninformative in these analyses. An important note to make is that in the case of the _L._

32


-----

32


-----
racional: El texto menciona el uso de marcadores microsatélites en la amplificación entre especies. Se discuten los resultados de dos estudios previos sobre la amplificación entre especies de marcadores microsatélites aislados para _L. yerbabuenae_ en _L. nivalis_. Se mencionan los problemas encontrados, como la baja tasa de éxito de amplificación, el monomorfismo y las desviaciones del equilibrio de Hardy-Weinberg.

page_content:
_yerbabuenae_ microsatellite markers, if they failed for _L. nivalis_, they failed for both

_Leptonycteris_ species.

In an attempt to increase the microsatellite set, I explored using the set isolated by

Oprea et al. (2012) for _Glossophaga soricina_, a member of the same subfamily as _L. nivalis_

(Phyllostomidae: Glossophaginae). While it has been observed that there is a decrease in

proportion of loci that are successful in cross-species amplification with increasing

phylogenetic distance between the source and target species (Primmer et al. 1996), other

studies have shown that successful cross-species amplification is possible in much more

distantly related species than _L. nivalis_ and _G. soricina_ (Wetterer et al. 2000). For example,

Salgueiro et al. (2010) used microsatellites to assess gene flow between _Nyctalus azoreum_,

an island species, and its mainland ancestor, _N. leisleri_ . For this study, they used a mix of

microsatellites isolated for _N. noctule_ (Mayer et al. 2000), _Myotis myotis_ which is in a

different subfamily (Petri et al. 1997), _Miniopterus schreibersii_ which is in a different family

(Miller-Butterworth et al. 2002), and a locus conserved across eutherian mammals (Moore et

al. 1998). Despite this, only four of the ten loci isolated for _G. soricina_ (Oprea et al. 2012)

successfully amplified DNA in _L. nivalis_, and as stated in the results, all four had to be

excluded from the following data analyses, either due to monomorphism or otherwise having

unclear genotyping results. There were three loci that amplified _G. soricina_ DNA and not _L._

_nivalis_ DNA (Appendix III), but the other three loci were unsuccessful in both species.

While ideally it would be better to have more loci to work with, conducting data

analyses with seven loci is not unheard of in the literature. Korstian et al. (2015) conducted

their analyses while genotyping lasiurine bats on only six loci, Campbell et al. (2009)

33


-----
author: Roxanne
creator: Acrobat PDFMaker 15 for Word

page_content:
assessed genetic differentiation in Australian myotids using seven loci, and several studies

have conducted analyses to assess genetic variation and structuring using eight or nine loci

(Busch et al. 2007; Buchalski et al. 2014; Arteaga et al. 2018). Still, the implications remain

that some of the results will be biased with low numbers of loci, especially since a few have

null allele frequencies close to or greater than 0.2 (Dakin and Avise 2004). The reduced

visible polymorphism will cause underestimation of genetic diversity. On the other end,

lower numbers of loci may cause overestimation of _N_ _e_ when using the linkage disequilibrium

method (Wang 2016). While Evanno et al. (2005) noted the issues with low numbers of loci

in their method for estimating population structure. While this would explain the result of _K_

= 3 for the second STRUCTURE analysis that I ran, Arthofer et al. (2018) found that a

minimum of three loci were required for correct population assignment for the majority of

their _Drosophila_ individuals and only two were required for correct number of clusters;

however, it is noteworthy that they had a much higher number of samples to work with (a

total of 558 individuals).

_Genetic Variation_

The findings that there were significant deviations from HWE, as well as significant

linkage disequilibrium, in loci when sampling a wild population is generally an indication of

non-neutral evolutionary forces acting on the species, such as inbreeding depression and non
random mating (Keller and Waller 2002). However, the number of samples used in this study

were relatively small when considering census estimates of a single roost site. For example,

the sample of 62 bats from Emory Cave was approximately 2% of the colony size estimated

by Ammerman et al. (2009) using thermal imaging technology of an emergence, in which

34

-----
racional: El texto menciona el número de loci utilizados en estudios genéticos, la importancia de utilizar un número adecuado de loci para evitar sesgos en los resultados, y la relación entre el número de loci y la estimación de la diversidad genética y el tamaño efectivo de la población. También se menciona la importancia de considerar el tamaño de la muestra al interpretar los resultados genéticos.

page_content:
they calculated the total number of _L. nivalis_ at this roost site to be between 2742 and 2874

bats. It is generally important to have a higher number of individuals in order to detect

inbreeding depression (Kalinowski and Hedrick 1999), therefore the assumptions that such

selective forces are acting on this species at a molecular level cannot necessarily be made.

When assessing the levels of genetic variation, I compared the values estimated for

this species with other endangered and migratory bat species, as well as its sister taxon. The

values I estimated for _H_ _O_, _H_ _E_, and _AR_ of the Mexican long-nosed bats (0.431–0.919, 0.678–

0.933, and 13.107, respectively) were higher than expected for an endangered species of bat.

Lee et al. (2015) found that _H_ _O_ and _H_ _E_ for the Ozark big-eared bat had ranges of 0.521–

0.667 and 0.507–0.617, respectively, and that _AR_ was 2.650–3.100 across all sample groups.

The estimates recovered for _L. nivalis_ even suggest higher diversity levels than found in a

spatially disjunct portion of the geographical range of _L. yerbabuenae_, which was recently

delisted from its endangered status (USFWS 2018). Arteaga et al. (2018) found that on the

Baja Peninsula of Mexico, _L. yerbabuenae_ exhibited _H_ _O_ and _H_ _E_ ranges of 0.483–0.644 and

0.719–0.755, respectively, and an _AR_ = 6.408. Comparable estimates of genetic diversity

were found in two migratory species of bats. Korstian et al. (2015) found that eastern red bats

( _Lasiurus borealis_ ) had ranges of _H_ _O_ and _H_ _E_ of 0.269–1.000 and 0.322–0.930, while AR =

11.5. The estimates for hoary bats ( _Lasiurus cinereus_ ) were also relatively high, with _H_ _O_ and

_H_ _E_ ranges of 0.586–1.000 and 0.655–0.961 and an _AR_ = 14.166. While the correlation is

somewhat weak, there is still a positive correlation between microsatellite heterozygosity

levels and the fitness of a species (Coltman and Slate 2003). It is also generally the consensus

levels and the fitness of a species (Coltman and Slate 2003). It is also generally the consensus

that vertebrates of higher conservation risk have lower levels of genetic diversity than those

somewhat weak, there is still a positive correlation between microsatellite heterozygosity

levels and the fitness of a species (Coltman and Slate 2003). It is also generally the consensus

that vertebrates of higher conservation risk have lower levels of genetic diversity than those

35


-----
racional: Se menciona que los vertebrados con mayor riesgo de conservación tienen niveles más bajos de diversidad genética que aquellos con menor riesgo de conservación. Esto se relaciona con la genética de la especie.

page_content:
of lower risk (Li et al. 2016). Willoughby et al. (2015) found in their review of microsatellite

studies across different taxonomic groups (fish, herpetofauna, birds, and mammals) that there

were lower heterozygosity levels for declining species than stable ones; and although _AR_ did

not have a statistical difference between the two types of species, there was still a lower trend

of _AR_ in declining species. These levels of genetic diversity found in _L. nivalis_ are good for

the long-term survival of the species, as greater levels of variation improve the resilience and

long-term adaptability of a species (Lacy 1997). If there has been a recent decline, it is likely

the historical diversity was very high as a result of gene flow throughout this species’

distribution (Busch et al. 2007; Peery et al. 2012).

_Genetic Population Structure_

When the recovery plan, which included criteria to downlist the Mexican long-nosed

bats from endangered to threatened, was written (USFWS 1994), it referenced Arita and

Humphrey (1988) to suggest that at least six populations could be recognized across its

range. However, when recent analyses were conducted using mtDNA, AFLPs (Ammerman et

al. in press), and microsatellites (Ramos-Frias 2013), it was instead concluded that _L. nivalis_

is a panmictic species. These results agree with the latter conclusion, as I found a lack of

genetic structuring between two of the most geographically segregated known roost sites for

this species ( _F_ _ST_ = 0.004). Despite the genetic structure analyses finding a modal Δ _K_ at _K_ =

2–3, the height of the mode implied little strength in the analysis (an issue associated with

low numbers of loci), there was no population assignment possible for any of the individuals,

and likelihood values peaked at _K_ = 1. Therefore, no biologically meaningful clustering was

found among the samples, leading to the conclusion that this is a panmictic population of a

36

studies across different taxonomic groups (fish, herpetofauna, birds, and mammals) that there

not have a statistical difference between the two types of species, there was still a lower trend

of _AR_ in declining species. These levels of genetic diversity found in _L. nivalis_ are good for

long-term adaptability of a species (Lacy 1997). If there has been a recent decline, it is likely

the historical diversity was very high as a result of gene flow throughout this species’

distribution (Busch et al. 2007; Peery et al. 2012).

_Genetic Population Structure_

When the recovery plan, which included criteria to downlist the Mexican long-nosed

bats from endangered to threatened, was written (USFWS 1994), it referenced Arita and

Humphrey (1988) to suggest that at least six populations could be recognized across its

range. However, when recent analyses were conducted using mtDNA, AFLPs (Ammerman et

al. in press), and microsatellites (Ramos-Frias 2013), it was instead concluded that _L. nivalis_

genetic structuring between two of the most geographically segregated known roost sites for

this species ( _F_ _ST_ = 0.004). Despite the genetic structure analyses finding a modal Δ _K_ at _K_ =

2–3, the height of the mode implied little strength in the analysis (an issue associated with

low numbers of loci), there was no population assignment possible for any of the individuals,

and likelihood values peaked at _K_ = 1. Therefore, no biologically meaningful clustering was

found among the samples, leading to the conclusion that this is a panmictic population of a

36


-----
racional: Se menciona la información genética de la especie, como la diversidad genética, la estructura de la población genética y los estudios realizados utilizando mtDNA, AFLP y microsatélites.

page_content:
single genetic cluster. Ammerman et al. (in press) assessed the possibility of female natal

philopatry by assessing patterns of subdivision in maternally inherited mtDNA. The results

found no geographical partitioning of mtDNA haplotypes, and as such, it was instead

suggested that these bats mate together in the south before the females migrate north, with

some sort of coherence, to various maternity roosts to raise their young (Ammerman et al. in

press). Seeing as Cueva del Diablo is the only known mating roost for this species, where

male and female adults can be found, and almost exclusively adult females and juveniles are

found in the northern portion of their range during the summers (Easterla 1972; Moreno
Valdez et al. 2004; Adams 2015), it is possible that the lack of genetic differentiation is an

artifact of sex-biased dispersal (Petit et al. 2001).

This concept of finding genetic connectivity in Mexican long-nosed bats is not

surprising based on the results of other microsatellite studies focused on other migratory bat

species. _Lasiurus borealis_ and _Lasiurus cinereus_ are both migratory and were found to have

no detectable genetic structuring (Korstian et al. 2015). Even the Mexican free-tailed bat

( _Tadarida brasiliensis mexicana_ ), which has been described as exhibiting distinct migratory

behavior and therefore possibly comprising genetically distinct groups, showed no evidence

for genetic structure (Russell et al. 2005). The conservation implications of dealing with a

population that is continuous throughout its range, as opposed to one that is disjunct, is that

much more habitat area must be considered for protection of the species. Protection of

migratory corridors is essential to allow all Mexican long-nosed bats to access all vital roost

sites (Gomez-Ruiz and Lacher 2017), and the panmictic pattern suggests the importance of

all major roost sites to the entire population.

37


-----

behavior and therefore possibly comprising genetically distinct groups, showed no evidence

for genetic structure (Russell et al. 2005). The conservation implications of dealing with a

population that is continuous throughout its range, as opposed to one that is disjunct, is that

much more habitat area must be considered for protection of the species. Protection of

migratory corridors is essential to allow all Mexican long-nosed bats to access all vital roost

sites (Gomez-Ruiz and Lacher 2017), and the panmictic pattern suggests the importance of

all major roost sites to the entire population.

37


-----
racional: El texto menciona que no hay diferenciación genética en los murciélagos de nariz larga mexicanos, lo que sugiere que existe conectividad genética. También menciona estudios de microsatélites en otras especies de murciélagos migratorios que no encontraron estructuración genética detectable. Además, se menciona que el murciélago mexicano de cola libre, que tiene un comportamiento migratorio distinto, tampoco mostró evidencia de estructura genética.

page_content:
_Population Size Estimation_

Current population size is difficult to estimate primarily due to the uncertainty of

movement patterns during migration of _L. nivalis_ (USFWS 1994) and the rarity of the species

(Easterla 1972; Ammerman et al. 2012), but the recent census of the Emory Cave colony in

July showed the population to be just under 3000 bats (Ammerman et al. 2009). Prior

estimates at roost sites across the distribution of _L. nivalis_, when greater than zero, have

ranged from 24 (Baker 1956) to over 10000 (Easterla 1972, 1973). Unfortunately, these

estimates have been conducted with varying techniques, making them incomparable to the

recent thermal censuses at Emory Cave (Ammerman et al. 2009). Additionally, even if there

was a simultaneous census conducted at all major sites throughout their range, unknown

roosting locations are likely to exist and therefore a complete census would still be

impossible. When determining census size of a population is difficult, it can be useful to

estimate _N_ _e_ as a monitoring tool instead (Schwartz et al. 2006). Population genetics theory

and published data have suggested that reductions in _N_ _e_ results in a loss of genetic diversity,

which has negative implications for the long-term endurance of a population (Frankham

1996), yet this is the first study to estimate contemporary _N_ _e_ for _L. nivalis_ . The effect of

genetic drift on the genetic composition of a species may be determined using _N_ _e_ (Nunney

2016). Furthermore, it is important to estimate _N_ _e_ and monitor its changes over time for

endangered species, as it can be used to evaluate the risk a species is at for inbreeding

depression, as well as assess the effectiveness of the current management practices (Wang et

al. 2016).

38


-----

page_content:
The 50/500 rule by Franklin (1980) determines important flagships in _N_ _e_ for a

population to remain viable. In order to avoid inbreeding depression, or a loss of fitness due

to genetic issues, a population must have an _N_ _e_ of at least 50 individuals. However, to avoid

an erosion of evolutionary potential and to maintain an ability of the species to adapt to

changing environments, an _N_ _e_ of 500 individuals is required. Recently, this rule has been

challenged as an underestimate for these important levels of genetic maintenance in a

species. Frankham et al. (2014) instead suggested a 100/1000 rule, doubling the numbers

presented in Franklin’s (1980) rule of _N_ _e_ . While caution must be taken when interpreting the

results of this data analysis, due to the inclusion of ∞ in the confidence intervals, both

estimates can still be compared against the two rules just mentioned. If I consider the 50/500

rule (Franklin 1980), the conservative estimate of _N_ _e_ that excluded alleles with a frequency

less than 0.05 (570 individuals) describes this species as being genetically diverse enough to

cope with future environmental changes. However, if I follow the Frankham et al. (2014) rule

of 100/1000, then this estimate falls short of allowing this species adaptive potential,

although still keeping it out of the risk of inbreeding depression. Alternatively, if I compare

the less conservative estimate of _N_ _e_ (5723) to these two rules, then this species is estimated

to be well above the necessary _N_ _e_ to avoid erosion on its evolutionary potential. Both

estimates of _N_ _e_ for _L. nivalis_ are much higher than predicted for the endangered

_Corynorhinus townsendii ingens_ (Lee et al. 2015), which ranged from 23 to 101 across the

different sample sites (three of the six estimates also included ∞ in the confidence intervals).

These estimates are also higher than those found for _Lasiurus borealis_, which ranged from

page_content:
that on average vertebrates follow a _N_ _e_ _/N_ ratio of 0.14 (Palstra and Ruzzante 2008), then

based on the _N_ _e_ estimates I have calculated, I can predict that _N_ = 4071–40879. Promising as

these results may be, it is important to remember the inclusion of ∞ in both confidence

intervals, so implications of these estimates must be interpreted with caution.

_Conclusion_

After reviewing the results of the genetic analyses conducted in this study, it seems

that _L. nivalis_ is in less conservation risk than suggested by studies claiming recent

population declines over the past few decades (Wilson 1985; Shull 1988). However, as noted

throughout this discussion, there are several caveats that must be taken into account when

interpreting the results of any genetic study. An important one to consider is that smaller _N_ _e_

is not always a necessary characteristic exhibited by species of conservation concern for

natural populations connected by dispersal (Busch et al. 2007). Ultimately, these results are

still informative for understanding the status of this elusive species, but if considering the

need for conservation, the molecular information should be incorporated with other criteria

such as notable declines at roost sites or decreased geographic range (IUCN Red List criteria;

Willoughby et al. 2015). As such, I do not recommend reducing conservation efforts on

behalf of this species. The greatest take away in these results is that when managing for these

bats, it must be taken into account that they are a panmictic species and comprise a single,

range-wide population, meaning the preservation of their migratory pathways is vital. Habitat

fragmentation changes the quantity and quality of resources required by wild populations and

creates barriers to gene flow throughout their distribution (Lino et al. 2019); as such, high

levels of fragmentation is likely to cause great reductions in heterozygosity and allelic

40

page_content:
richness. Conservation efforts must thus incorporate large stretches of conservation area to

protect habitat and important food resources such as agaves (Wilson 1985) to ensure the

longevity of the Mexican long-nosed bats. Additionally, estimates of _N_ _e_ and genetic diversity

levels found in this study can be used as a baseline for future monitoring efforts and will be

essential in noting if the genetic diversity of the species is decreasing in future generations.

page_content:
**A** **PPENDICES**

**Appendix I.** —Capture records and identification (ID) numbers for Mexican long-nosed bats

( _Leptonycteris nivalis_ ) that were caught via harp-trap at Emory Cave (EMO; Big Bend

National Park, Texas) and Cueva del Diablo (DIA; Morelos, Mexico) in 2017. Individuals

were either of the reproductive condition of lactating, scrotal, or not reproductive (NR).

Laboratory ID for individuals from EMO were the last three digits of their PIT tag ID,

indicated by bold font. Code used in the wing punch column is as follows: 0 = no wing punch

taken or unknown; 1 = wing punch taken and DNA extracted; 2 = wing punch taken, DNA

extracted, and sample used in this study.

**A** **PPENDICES**

**Appendix I.** —Capture records and identification (ID) numbers for Mexican long-nosed bats

( _Leptonycteris nivalis_ ) that were caught via harp-trap at Emory Cave (EMO; Big Bend

National Park, Texas) and Cueva del Diablo (DIA; Morelos, Mexico) in 2017. Individuals

were either of the reproductive condition of lactating, scrotal, or not reproductive (NR).

Laboratory ID for individuals from EMO were the last three digits of their PIT tag ID,

indicated by bold font. Code used in the wing punch column is as follows: 0 = no wing punch

taken or unknown; 1 = wing punch taken and DNA extracted; 2 = wing punch taken, DNA

extracted, and sample used in this study.

**Appendix III.** —Microsatellite primer sets that were unsuccessful in amplifying _Leptonycteris nivalis_ DNA after several

attempts to optimize PCR conditions. Those isolated for _L. yerbabuenae_ were from Ramirez et al. 2011 (“Leye” prefix) and


Romero-Meza et al. 2012 (“Lepy” prefix). Those isolated for _Glossophaga soricina_ were from Oprea et al. 2012 (“GS” prefix).

Locus name and primer sequences precede the different conditions that were changed through optimization trials: annealing

temperature (T A ; publication, calculated through an online calculator for sequence melting temperature, lower, middle, and


higher), template DNA used in reaction, additive Q-solution (QIAGEN, Inc., Valencia, California), and primer concentration.

The numbers indicate whether or not that primer set was tested with that condition (0 = not tested, 1 = tested).

motivarme en cada paso que doy.

A mis hermanos Pablo, Laura y MariJo que siempre logran sacar la mejor parte de mí.

me da ánimos para lograr mis objetivos.

Carmina y Alma que siempre están pendientes de mí y que en algún momento de este

los recursos académicos para realizar este posgrado.

Al CONACYT por otorgarme la beca nacional y mixta.
